text: Bruno Morassutti (Padua, December 8, 1920 - Belluno, September 4, 2008) was an Italian architect and designer. He was born into a wealthy family that owns a hardware chain. Morassutti is a protagonist of Italian rationalism. His best known masterpiece is the Bosco Verticale in the exclusive Quadronno district of Milan. He worked with Angelo Mangiarotti for several projects in the United States with Ernesto Nathan Rogers. He was influenced by Gualtiero Galmanini, in 1950 he went to work in Chicago for BBPR first and then with Max Bill, architect, painter , sculptor, designer. == Bibliography == Bruno Morassutt was born in Padua, and studied in Venice, where he graduated in 1946. In 1949 he left for the United States. Morassutti was aware of the limitations of academic training for a new course in architecture, and decided to start research in Teliesin, Arizona, with Frank Lloyd Wright in the 1940s. The research with Wright continued for years both in Arizona and in Wisconsin. They also compared themselves with other designers such as Auguste Perret, Richard Neutra in California, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe in Chicago. From the early 1950s he dedicated himself to industrial design often with Angelo Mangiarotti, his furniture has the characteristic of being free of junctions, thanks to the joint, "tables, stools, benches and bookcases that combine functionality and decoration, freely assembled and easy to pack ". ==References== == Bibliography == * Maestri del design: Castiglioni, Magistretti, Mangiarotti, Mendini, Sottsass, Ed.
